Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ATD: Dynamical sampling and reconstruction for sensing networks of physical fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs develop and test the theory and algorithms for a new sampling and reconstruction framework that combines spatial samples of an initial state together with the early time samples of an evolving state to reconstruct the initial distribution and the possibly unknown evolution operator. Using the evolutionary nature of a signal, the PIs aim to recover an initial distribution at a fine resolution from multiple coarse snapshots obtained at appropriate time intervals.


One of the most important aspects of the proposed research is to provide the means to detect potential threats to society (such as chemical, nuclear or biological hazards) using a network of distributed sensors such as the smartphones people carry, rapidly gather and process the information about the threats source location and its distribution and evolution in time, and generate alerts so that appropriate measures are taken to safeguard life and infrastructure. The same ideas can be used in other industrial or biomedical applications in which the time-dependency between samples permits reduction in the number of expensive instruments via the increase of their usage frequency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PIs and collaborators have created a mathematical framework and algorithms for processing evolving signals that model potential threats such as pollution, chemical or biological hazards, and natural disasters. The framework is named Dynamical Sampling to emphasize that the information about the signals is gathered at different moments in time and at sparse spatial locations. This new mathematical framework provides techniques for identifying sources and evaluating the severity of threats of various kind. Identifying the sources is crucial for understanding the nature of the threat and identifying the evolution operators is helpful in predicting and controlling the outcome of the developing emergency. Both of these enhance the ability to devise an appropriate response and safeguard life and infrastructure.

The solved problems in Dynamical Sampling include the space-time trade-off in sampling schemes, system identification, and phaseless reconstructions from dynamical samples. The results of the research were published in numerous articles and presented at national and international conferences. The developed algorithms were tested on synthetic and real data. Several Ph.D. students (including underrepresented minorities) have been trained in both theoretical and applied aspects of Dynamical Sampling. Research in Dynamical Sampling has motivated related investigations in various areas of pure and applied mathematics by several groups of mathematicians and engineers. The theory of Dynamical Sampling gave rise to new important problems and it continues to develop.
